name: Eland Antelope
description: The eland antelope is the second-largest antelope species in the world, surpassed only by the very similar Derby’s eland. Its distinctive features include sandy coloration with lighter transverse stripes, a dark mane, and spiral horns up to 70 cm long.
image_alt: Eland antelope, photo: Tomáš Adamec, Prague Zoo
proportions: Body length 2–3.5 m; tail length 50–90 cm; shoulder height 1.2–1.8 m; weight 300–950 kg
attractions: They form large herds, often mixed with zebras and other antelope species. They don’t occupy fixed territories, and there’s no strict social hierarchy within the herd, so conflicts are rare. Only during mating season do males drive off rivals with ritualized threats, mock-charging nearby bushes, grass clumps, or fallen logs. Eland antelopes are easily tamed, and efforts are underway to domesticate them and expand their farming. In some parts of Africa, their resilience makes them far better suited than traditional livestock.
breeding: The first two eland antelopes arrived at Prague Zoo in 1955—females who lived there for three years. Modern breeding began in 2002.
